thread.title: Gay marriage in Australia: equality push gets Evan Wolfson’s boost
thread.title_full: Gay marriage in Australia: equality push gets Evan Wolfson’s boost | Daily Telegraph

author: Shannon Molloy
title: Gay marriage in Australia: equality push gets Evan Wolfson’s boost
text:
SAME-sex marriage will happen in Australia sooner rather than later, the architect of the successful US campaign for equality says, and he’s coming down to help.
Evan Wolfson was the founder of Freedom to Marry , a strategic hub for the national equality battle in America that ultimately won in 2015 .
Since being “gladly” put out of work, the lawyer has travelled the world helping activists in other countries. As he turns his sights to Australia, he’s confident of another victory .
“This is the moment — this is the time,” Wolfson said.
“You guys are so far ahead of where we were when we won. You have more public support and you have an entire global track record to point to, showing that ending marriage discrimination doesn’t hurt anyone and isn’t a leap into the dark.”
Over the course of four decades of activism, Wolfson helped take the American homosexual community from “a despised minority” to recipients of the legal right to marry.
With momentum for change in Australia growing — consistent polling shows support at around 70 per cent — Wolfson has a wealth of advice for the local campaign.
media_camera Evan Wolfson with former US Vice President Joe Biden at a Freedom To Marry celebration event after the Supreme Court ruling in 2015. Picture: Getty Images
Applying pressure to politicians is critical in keeping the issue on the agenda, he said. Even those in favour should be reminded.
“Right now, this is the moment we really need elected officials to hear from families across Australia — gay and non-gay families need to make their voices heard.
“Contact them, tell them you want them to get the job done.”
media_camera Public support for marriage equality is growing and Evan Wolfson believes “now is the time” to get it done. Picture: AFP Photo
Another strategy is pointing to countless global examples , from the US and UK to Ireland, Portugal, Brazil, South Africa and New Zealand, where “the sky hasn’t fallen in” after change.
“Nothing bad happens when couples are allowed to strengthen their committed love,” he said. “Everybody wins, nobody loses.”
Trailer
